p: This empirical reality should shape the decisions of policymakers and lead them to craft climate policies that directly address the intersectionality of people’s lives. Treating climate as a siloed issue is not only inaccurate analysis but also it leads to politically dangerous solutions, such as the ‘carbon fundamentalist approach’, which emphasizes market-based solutions for reducing carbon emissions at the expense of working-class people. Such an approach can have disastrous political and socioeconomic implications, as we’ve seen in Australia and France, where each government has pushed carbon taxes and faced significant public backlash.
